User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8.0.3) Gecko/20060425 SUSE/1.5.0.3-7 Firefox/1.5.0.3 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8.0.3) Gecko/20060425 SUSE/1.5.0.3-7 Firefox/1.5.0.3 IE does this correctly, Firefox does not. If a CSS file contains a reference to a relative URL in list-style-image, the location should start from the directory containing the CSS file, NOT the directory containing the HTML page. Reason: the CSS file is mentioning the image, and so the CSS file cannot be portably reused by multiple pages if the relativity does not follow the CSS file. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: css/web.css: li { list-style-image: url(asterisk.gif); } t.html:
  • Hi
Use any image file for "asterisk.gif". Store in same directory as t.html. Displays. Store in same directory as web.css. Does not display. Actual Results: Firefox fails to display asterisk.gif when stored in css directory. Expected Results: Firefox should display asterisk.gif when stored in css directory. I marked this major, because if you leave it sround too long, people will recode their pages to adapt to this bug.

OK, I went back to check with one of my developers.  He was actually using Flock.  I'm not sure why the difference in behavior.  Should I report this to Flock developers?

Here is what he said:  "The zip that you send me *does work* in FF (Mozilla 5.0, Gecko/20060728 Firefox/1.5.0.6), I was previously testing with Flock, and it does not work with Flock (Mozilla 5.0, Gecko/20060620 Firefox/1.5.0.4). It also does not wirk with Flock 0.7.4.1 (Mozilla 5.0, Gecko/20060731 Firefox/1.5.0.5).  It has always worked in IE 6."

Sorry for the FF/Flock confusion.
